message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of a testicular mass requires further evaluation to rule out testicular cancer. Testicular ultrasound is the imaging modality of choice to assess testicular masses. Needle biopsy is contraindicated due to the risk of spreading the cancer, CT abdomen and pelvis may be considered as a follow-up to the ultrasound but it's not the initial management step, and sending labs is not specific enough to assess the nature of the mass.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s presentation is concerning for testicular cancer. Testicular ultrasound is the best next step in management to evaluate the mass and determine if it is suspicious for cancer. Needle biopsy is not recommended in case the mass is cancerous as it can lead to the spread of cancer cells. CT abdomen and pelvis is not indicated at this time and sending labs alone will not provide enough information to diagnose or manage the situation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Given the patient's symptoms and physical exam findings, the best next step in management is testicular ultrasound. This will confirm the presence of the mass and help to determine whether it is solid or cystic. Needle biopsy is not typically recommended for testicular masses, as it carries a risk of spreading cancer cells. CT abdomen and pelvis may be indicated if there is concern for metastasis, but this is not the first step in management. Sending labs is nonspecific and would not help to diagnose the cause of the mass.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s presentation raises suspicion for testicular cancer and the best next step in management is to perform a testicular ultrasound. Needle biopsy is not recommended due to risk of seeding along the needle track. CT abdomen and pelvis may be ordered later but are not the initial step. Labs may be ordered but alone will not provide a definitive diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a testicular mass, and testicular ultrasound is the gold standard imaging modality for evaluating testicular masses. Needle biopsy or sending labs may help with diagnosis but are not the best initial step in management. CT abdomen and pelvis can be considered if there is concern for metastasis after further evaluation with ultrasound.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The next step in management should be a testicular ultrasound to determine if the mass is solid or cystic in nature. A needle biopsy could potentially cause seeding of malignant cells, and a CT scan should not be the first step in management. Sending labs is also not the best next step as it will not provide a definitive diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A testicular mass requires further evaluation to rule out malignancy. Testicular ultrasound is the best next step to assess the size, location, and characteristics of the mass. Needle biopsy can potentially spread malignant cells and is not recommended as a first-line test. CT abdomen and pelvis may be useful in staging after malignancy is confirmed, but is not the first step in diagnosis. Sending labs is also not specific enough to diagnose a testicular mass.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of a non-tender, non-reducible mass in the testicle is highly suspicious for testicular cancer. Testicular ultrasound is the best next step in management to evaluate the mass and determine if it is cancerous. Needle biopsy or CT imaging may also be done, but testicular ultrasound is more specific and sensitive. Labs may be sent to assess for tumor markers, but the imaging study is needed first for diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s presentation is concerning for a testicular mass, which may be malignant. The best next step in management is a testicular ultrasound, which can provide additional information on the nature of the mass and help guide further management. Needle biopsy is not recommended as it can lead to seeding of cancer cells. CT abdomen and pelvis may be done for staging but should not be the initial step. Sending labs is not specific enough to provide a diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A testicular ultrasound is the gold standard for evaluating a testicular mass. Needle biopsy or CT abdomen and pelvis may be considered after the ultrasound, depending on the results. Labs may be ordered but are not the best next step in management for a testicular mass.
